children.subject:
Just from my personal experience as someone who wasn’t able to declare CS — I don’t think you’ll have trouble finding a job as a software engineer. At least when I was applying to jobs, I felt like because I had strong knowledge of the relevant material (& as a result I felt like every interview I got went well) potential future employers didn’t really care that I have a pretty bad GPA. Especially if you do well in your upper div classes, have relevant experience, and do some good projects, I don’t think having applied math on your resume rather than CS will hurt your job prospects in any significant way. 

This isn’t something I know a ton about, but grad school could be a bigger issue — grad schools do care a lot about your grades. However, an upward trend in your grades will be viewed really favorably, and good research experience / good letters of rec can definitely make up a bit for deficiencies in your grades. And, even if your grades keep you from getting into some MSCS programs, you don’t necessarily need to go to a super high ranked program to meet your goals.

history.content:
Hi everyone,

                 I am little worried about declaring CS and not meeting the gpa . I spend lot of time thinking about what will happen if I don't meet the gpa cut off . So my question is if end up declaring applied math(with cs cluster) , will it hurt my chances getting into machine learning research or master in cs with focus in AI and machine learning.  Also will it hurt my job prospects as a software engineer ? Even if  I end up declaring applied math I will still have most of cs classes .

                                                                Thank you!!
history.subject: Worried about Declaring cs
